F72522A36F3A47A79BECE4AEA9E2A41A.description: give examples of applications of atomic and nuclear phenomena using the standard model such as nuclear stability, fission and fusion, radiation therapy, diagnostic imaging, semiconductors, superconductors, solar cells, and nuclear power and examples of applications of quantum phenomena.

F6D4ADE944EE419C86CB5AE547A92A9C.description: calculate and describe the applications of mass-energy equivalence; and

C3F50E0348E44F67A8307E68EF3B4B21.description: compare and explain the emission spectra produced by various atoms;

2B97EF864A074D7290D5D90C84EF9161.description: describe the photoelectric effect and the dual nature of light;

B77E04878980437583F9FEF37094CFB8.description: Science concepts. The student knows simple examples of atomic, nuclear, and quantum phenomena. The student is expected to:

622BC93BE5C347E5BC7C8AD8E3BBEA30.description: describe and predict image formation as a consequence of reflection from a plane mirror and refraction through a thin convex lens.

FF9A37CEFBC2483FAB902588B8A51AC3.description: investigate behaviors of waves, including reflection, refraction, diffraction, interference, resonance, and the Doppler effect; and

962CB0CB21F84520BE387374D0D66A4F.description: compare characteristics and behaviors of transverse waves, including electromagnetic waves and the electromagnetic spectrum, and characteristics and behaviors of longitudinal waves, including sound waves;

FE4FC17BB37F461BAEE2997B57322AD2.description: investigate and analyze characteristics of waves, including velocity, frequency, amplitude, and wavelength, and calculate using the relationship between wavespeed, frequency, and wavelength;

DF57A2106DBF401C8AAB356F5BD80037.description: examine and describe oscillatory motion and wave propagation in various types of media;

D18C8BFC81B5484AA3109ADDE89698DB.description: Science concepts. The student knows the characteristics and behavior of waves. The student is expected to:

0576EDA1DA384B90B58C06D36FC7460F.description: explain everyday examples that illustrate the four laws of thermodynamics and the processes of thermal energy transfer.

4D6A05B262924E4BB8EE4D93637C5B5B.description: demonstrate and apply the laws of conservation of energy and conservation of momentum in one dimension; and

D522347BF3994031BA3F6B69319A8DCB.description: calculate the mechanical energy of, power generated within, impulse applied to, and momentum of a physical system;

2D9FC0535E0C4F06A97FF326B75255FF.description: investigate examples of kinetic and potential energy and their transformations;

313E043DCE6D4DFEACDD82D0623A8C9A.description: investigate and calculate quantities using the work-energy theorem in various situations;

5E73D9A485B746D8AC2300BBAA371402.description: Science concepts. The student knows that changes occur within a physical system and applies the laws of conservation of energy and momentum. The student is expected to:

7F2720AB6CC74F489441B29E50345D7A.description: investigate and calculate current through, potential difference across, resistance of, and power used by electric circuit elements connected in both series and parallel combinations.

35F851D8ADED498B9BA144738A852758.description: characterize materials as conductors or insulators based on their electric properties; and

3524FB43D2134D89AF189C6A32215DDD.description: identify and describe examples of electric and magnetic forces and fields in everyday life such as generators, motors, and transformers;

FF3C38CADE4143ADB6D2A61EC6EC01C6.description: describe and calculate how the magnitude of the electric force between two objects depends on their charges and the distance between their centers;

165F964EB8FE41B7A7AEEFDDEFC0DB2A.description: describe and calculate how the magnitude of the gravitational force between two objects depends on their masses and the distance between their centers;

9C5B5F19F0754F8A8BBFB983A754A2AA.description: describe the concepts of gravitational, electromagnetic, weak nuclear, and strong nuclear forces;

F6E747687A254E7890BAFAAB2BA12EFE.description: Science concepts. The student knows the nature of forces in the physical world. The student is expected to:

3AE4CDBE246247AD856CA629A0C1F5E1.description: calculate the effect of forces on objects, including the law of inertia, the relationship between force and acceleration, and the nature of force pairs between objects using methods, including free-body force diagrams.

65119756224046C2B1F1995AA4C0146E.description: analyze and describe accelerated motion in two dimensions, including using equations, graphical vector addition, and projectile and circular examples; and

1686C632AB1D48ADAF33BEA8DC160C6D.description: describe and analyze motion in one dimension using equations and graphical vector addition with the concepts of distance, displacement, speed, average velocity, instantaneous velocity, frames of reference, and acceleration;

A5DAD89C0CD5485EA1C87C5DAA2C4200.description: generate and interpret graphs and charts describing different types of motion, including investigations using real-time technology such as motion detectors or photogates;

FDFF15C7383E4FFB9C008C662A78CD41.description: Science concepts. The student knows and applies the laws governing motion in a variety of situations. The student is expected to:

D3CD0A400BB74192A746A195AAC55044.description: express, manipulate, and interpret relationships symbolically in accordance with accepted theories to make predictions and solve problems mathematically.

E742EC537A0C4443873E558D77448ACB.description: research and describe the connections between physics and future careers; and

AF0D6DEE69914B47919304DB8E73FBC0.description: explain the impacts of the scientific contributions of a variety of historical and contemporary scientists on scientific thought and society;

DCEEB1A4BE32437A8068CD4D7643D02A.description: communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as current events, news reports, published journal articles, and marketing materials;

2543386CD8834545ABC5A897148B0BD3.description: analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, so as to encourage critical thinking by the student;

6130BD93AD8845D294B9323E455145B3.description: Scientific processes. The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions within and outside the classroom. The student is expected to:

B0077010C41541BEBA4FFB54AF27C091.description: express relationships among physical variables quantitatively, including the use of graphs, charts, and equations.

16BEEF4DCE5D4EF19EFD44C447A59575.description: communicate valid conclusions supported by the data through various methods such as lab reports, labeled drawings, graphic organizers, journals, summaries, oral reports, and technology-based reports; and

8363356CFA8F473E8F5BE528C3E711CB.description: organize, evaluate, and make inferences from data, including the use of tables, charts, and graphs;

14A04DFB0ECE480B8C7A45162CFF8E5A.description: make measurements with accuracy and precision and record data using scientific notation and International System (SI) units;

02AA708C457F4664ABAD3D18E5701C4F.description: use a wide variety of additional course apparatus, equipment, techniques, materials, and procedures as appropriate such as ripple tank with wave generator, wave motion rope, tuning forks, hand-held visual spectroscopes, discharge tubes with power supply (H, He, Ne, Ar), electromagnetic spectrum charts, laser pointers, micrometer, caliper, computer, data acquisition probes, scientific calculators, graphing technology, electrostatic kits, electroscope, inclined plane, optics bench, optics kit, polarized film, prisms, pulley with table clamp, motion detectors, photogates, friction blocks, ballistic carts or equivalent, resonance tube, stroboscope, resistors, copper wire, switches, iron filings, and/or other equipment and materials that will produce the same results;

F7CB08669064485EA6D8F4766AA66C9A.description: demonstrate the use of course apparatus, equipment, techniques, and procedures, including multimeters (current, voltage, resistance), balances, batteries, dynamics demonstration equipment, collision apparatus, lab masses, magnets, plane mirrors, convex lenses, stopwatches, trajectory apparatus, graph paper, magnetic compasses, protractors, metric rulers, spring scales, thermometers, slinky springs, and/or other equipment and materials that will produce the same results;

6B7111C0D9E3488E8213BB4B378FC2F1.description: design and implement investigative procedures, including making observations, asking well defined questions, formulating testable hypotheses, identifying variables, selecting appropriate equipment and technology, evaluating numerical answers for reasonableness, and identifying causes and effects of uncertainties in measured data;

2CF0CA109B3F4830AD734F67B82475C1.description: know that scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well established and highly reliable explanations, but may be subject to change;

E76F0CBC26EA4C9E957279AF50F0C4A4.description: know that scientific hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence;

81C943A7C86E456EB3F3596AE52A0047.description: know the definition of science and understand that it has limitations, as specified in subsection (b)(2) of this section;

BA72DAF48F434957BAECE31E58A04F67.description: Scientific processes. The student uses a systematic approach to answer scientific laboratory and field investigative questions. The student is expected to:

D64C5DB0D7614BB6B9CD38D547D5BA36.description: demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper disposal or recycling of materials.

006BE11CFD3F40998B6D6FDA009E6CA7.description: demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations; and

AC28025205394050BE3C9E9A468B2963.description: Scientific processes. The student conducts investigations, for at least 40% of instructional time, using safe, environmentally appropriate, and ethical practices. These investigations must involve actively obtaining and analyzing data with physical equipment but may also involve experimentation in a simulated environment as well as field observations that extend beyond the classroom. The student is expected to:

837E7F4120D44CD49B284468F21769C0.description: Statements containing the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

5147E7A0046747BE8028DB5AF118DAB4.description: Scientific systems. A system is a collection of cycles, structures, and processes that interact. All systems have basic properties that can be described in terms of space, time, energy, and matter. Change and constancy occur in systems as patterns and can be observed, measured, and modeled. These patterns help to make predictions that can be scientifically tested. Students should analyze a system in terms of its components and how these components relate to each other, to the whole, and to the external environment.

E5D81CC819F145F1AB52CC9ABA901D4F.description: Science and social ethics. Scientific decision making is a way of answering questions about the natural world. Students should be able to distinguish between scientific decision-making methods and ethical and social decisions that involve the application of scientific information.

CDC789A8EFD348E49562FF82A4B572D2.description: Scientific inquiry. Scientific inquiry is the planned and deliberate investigation of the natural world. Scientific methods of investigation can be experimental, descriptive, or comparative. The method chosen should be appropriate to the question being asked.

2362E1EC70654464ACF8E447D711800A.description: Nature of science. Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not currently scientifically testable by empirical science.

D86E7932B7D445D9852F3463DD3E389B.description: Physics. In Physics, students conduct laboratory and field investigations, use scientific practices during investigations, and make informed decisions using critical thinking and scientific problem solving. Students study a variety of topics that include: laws of motion; changes within physical systems and conservation of energy and momentum; forces; thermodynamics; characteristics and behavior of waves; and atomic, nuclear, and quantum physics. Students who successfully complete Physics will acquire factual knowledge within a conceptual framework, practice experimental design and interpretation, work collaboratively with colleagues, and develop critical-thinking skills.

5FA4298347E14AEB8C15760966D63164.description: General requirements. Students shall be awarded one credit for successful completion of this course. Algebra I is suggested as a prerequisite or corequisite. This course is recommended for students in Grade 9, 10, 11, or 12.
